info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued March 26 at 2:37AM PDT by NWS Reno
info.description: ...COOLER TEMPS, BREEZY WINDS, WITH RAIN AND SNOW SHOWERS LATE SUNDAY INTO MONDAY... After several days of record-breaking high temperatures, an incoming storm will bring the return of more typical early spring weather. * Another afternoon of breezy westerly winds today, with winds turning southerly and increasing further on Sunday. Most gusts will be in the 30-40 mph range on Sunday for valley locations with typical travel and recreational impacts. Sierra ridges may gust above 80 mph Sunday afternoon through Monday morning. * Valley rain and mountain snow will reach the Sierra late Sunday night into Monday morning, spreading into western Nevada Monday and Monday night. Liquid totals remain light overall with the highest totals favoring the Sierra crest from Tahoe south through Mono County, and portions of the eastern Sierra and western Nevada south of US-50. There may be a large variation in liquid totals over short distances due to the showery nature of the system. There is also a slight chance for thunderstorms to develop Monday. * Snow levels will remain near 6000 feet, with accumulation likely to be limited to passes above 7000 feet due to the recent warmth and late-March sun angle. The high Sierra could pick up 4-10 inches of snow, locally higher in southern Mono County. Be prepared for winter conditions and give yourself extra travel time if crossing the Sierra. * While nothing out of the ordinary, it will be significantly cooler Monday compared to the recent warmth and highs may struggle to reach 60 degrees in the warmest of valleys.
